title: TESS 2: A Large-Scale Generalist Diffusion Language Model
author: Jaesung Tae (Yale University), Hamish Ivison (University of Washington), Sachin Kumar (Allen Institute for AI), Arman Cohan (Yale University), ...
relevance_why: The paper introduces the TESS 2 model, which is a large-scale diffusion language model. The techniques for improving language generation through diffusion methods may inform similar approaches in audio-language integration and generative audio tasks in Haohe Liu's research.
background: This research develops a diffusion-based language model that adapts autoregressive models and enhances instruction-following capabilities.
contribution: TESS 2 introduces a novel framework for adapting autoregressive models into instruction-following diffusion language models, achieving significant improvements in diverse downstream tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous diffusion models focused on specific intrinsic metrics like perplexity and often lacked scalability or flexibility in application.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work successfully adapts existing autoregressive models for broad instruction-following capabilities, significantly outperforming prior diffusion models and matching autoregressive benchmarks.

key_innovation: The use of continuous diffusion processes alongside innovative guide techniques for inference allows for improved language model control and adaptability.
real_world_impact: The improved instruction-following capabilities of TESS 2 could enhance various AI applications, such as chatbots and virtual assistants, benefiting practical user interactions in technology.
limitations: The model may still lag behind autoregressive models in reasoning tasks, indicating room for future enhancements.
open_sourcing: Code and models are available at https://github.com/hamishivi/tess-2
